document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the spider genus Sparianthis Simon, 1880 (Araneae, Sparassidae Sparianthinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the spider genus Sparianthis Simon, 1880 (Araneae, Sparassidae Sparianthinae)

subSubSection.paragraph:

.

Additional material examined.
BRAZIL :
Pará
:
1♀ , Juruti , Vista Bela , pista de Pouso ( -3.1167 , -56.5852 ),
2 October 2009
, N.F. Lo Man Hung leg. ( MPEG 15792 )
;
1♀ , Santarém , Altér do Chão , Paraíso [ -2.5000 , -54.9500 ],
17 July 2007
, B.J.F. Silva leg. ( MPEG 30630 )
.
Etymology. The specific name refers to the Boraris indigenous community, that inhabited the region of Altér do Ch ã o until the early 18 th century; noun in apposition.

Diagnosis. Males of
S. boraris
sp. nov.
resemble those of
S. megalopalpa
by the palp with mRTA as long as vRTA and longer than dRTA ( Figs 28 , 116 ). They are distinguished from the latter species by vRTA bifid in retrolateral view, with one branch short and blunt and the other longer and conical, and mRTA long, sharply pointed in ventral view and rectangular in retrolateral view (vRTA single branched, conical and mRTA bifid, with two truncated branches in retrolateral view in
S. megalopalpa
) ( Figs 27–28 ). Females resemble those of
S. caracarai
sp. nov.
and
S. ravida
by the epigyne with anterior atrium smooth, as long as wide or slightly longer than wide ( Figs 29 , 36 , 140 ). They are distinguished from
S. caracarai
sp. nov.
by anterior atrium larger than median septum and vulva with first turn anteriad (anterior atrium smaller than median septum and first turn mediad in
S. caracarai
sp. nov.
), and from
S. ravida
by median septum widest anteriorly and vulva with spermathecae elongate (median septum widest posteriorly and spermathecae rounded in
S. ravida
) ( Figs 29–31 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 17–20.
Sparianthis boraris
sp. nov.
, habitus. 17–18 male, paratype (MPEG 30638) (17 dorsal, 18 ventral); 19–20 female (MPEG 15792) (19 dorsal, 20 ventral). Scale lines: 2 mm.

FIGURES 21–25.
Sparianthis boraris
sp. nov.
21–23 male, paratype (MPEG 30638) left palp (21 prolateral, 22 ventral, 23 retrolateral); 24–25 female, paratype (MPEG 30636) (24 epigyne, 25 vulva). Scale lines: 1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Description. Female ( paratype , MPEG 30369):
Coloration pattern generally lighter than male. Prosoma with fovea barely conspicuous and no lines along thoracic striae. Opisthosoma dorsally with irregular marks laterally, faint smudged area around cardiac mark, one median chevron and three median triangles down posterior half; ventrally with few scattered spots laterally on posterior half and no visible muscle sigilla ( Figs 19–20 ). Total length 10.1. Prosoma: 4.8 long, 3.8 wide. Opisthosoma: 5.1 long, 3.4 wide. Eyes: diameters: 0.32, 0.24, 0.18, 0.24; interdistances: 0.25, 0.15, 0.55, 0.35, 0.17, 0.09. Legs (2143): I: 13.7 (4.0, 2.1, 3.7, 3.2, 0.7); II: 13.8 (4.3, 2.2, 3.4, 3.21, 0.7); III: 10.4 (3.5, 1.7, 2.2, 2.4, 0.6); IV: 13.2 (4.1, 1.5, 2.9, 3.7, 1.0). Spination follows the generic pattern. Metatarsi III–IV with ventral distal preening combs. Epigyne: epigynal field rectangular, slightly longer than wide; anterior atrium squared, as long as wide; median septum 1.5 times longer than wide, with posterior margin rounded ( Figs 24 , 29 ). Vulva: internal ducts slender, half spermathecae width; glandular projection rounded, arising from duct at first turn ( Figs 25 , 30–31 ).
Variation . Males (n = 3): total length 9.0–10.0; prosoma length 4.4–4.6; femur I length 3.8–4.3. Females (n = 5): total length 9.0–12.6; prosoma length 4.3–5.0; femur I length 3.4–4.2.
Distribution . Known from Brazil , western state of Pará ( Fig. 144 ).
